items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon and overnight tonight, into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boatyards and Ferry Road in Horning. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 3 December.

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of snow-melt, and additional rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Thursday 02/12/21. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Thursday afternoon, 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of snow-melt, and additional rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Thursday 02/12/21, around the Naburn area. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Thursday afternoon, 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force. River levels have risen as a result of rainfall and snowmelt over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Thursday 02/12/2021. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Thursday afternoon 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences at Seaburn Lower Promenade and Seaham Harbour and Docks as a result of this afternoon’s high tide and strong winds. Wave overtopping is expected between 11:45 and 16:15 today, 02/12/2021. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 02/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. The forecast is for dry conditions today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 3 December	.
